localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the blood pressure measurement.
Additional narrative about the measurement, not captured in other fields.
The position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side.   Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement.  For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
The individual is fully conscious.
The individual is in the natural state of bodily rest.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
A cuff used for an adult thigh.
A cuff for adults with larger arms.
A cuff that is standard for an adult.
A cuff used for a small adult.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm.
A cuff used for infants.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.

annotations.comment: Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.

localizedDescriptions.en: Simple body site where blood pressure was measured.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
The right wrist of the individual.
The left wrist of the individual.
The right ankle of the individual.
The left ankle of the individual.
A finger of the individual.
A toe of the individual.
The individual's dorsum of the foot.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery.
A physical site on or within the human body.
Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.

annotations.comment:
This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.

This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.

If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional detail using a specific region or a point on, or within, the identified body site.

annotations.comment: Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. For example, the upper right quadrant or McBurney's point on the abdominal wall or interphalangeal joint of the great toe. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the specific site, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The side of the body on which the identified  body site is located.
Left side of the body.
Right side of the body.

annotations.comment:
If the identified body site has no laterality, this data element should not have a value. 
If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include laterality, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Qualifying detail about the specific aspect of the identified body site.
Towards the midline of the body site.
Towards the side, or edge, of the body site.
Above the body site, often meaning towards the head.
Below the body site, often meaning towards the feet.
Towards the front, or ventral surface, of  the body site.
Towards the back, or dorsal surface, of the body site.
More central or closer to the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
More peripheral, or further from the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
Away from the surface of the body site.
Towards the surface of the body site.
Towards the palm of the hand.
Towards the sole of the foot.
Towards the back of the hand or top of the foot. To be used as opposites of palmar or plantar, not as a synonym of posterior.
In the middle of the body site.
Towards the mouth. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.
Towards the anus. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.

annotations.comment: Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. For example: proximal urethra; plantar aspect of the left thumb. Multiple aspects can also be described, if required, by allowing for 0..2 occurrences. For example: a lesion may be on the left anterior/lateral (ie anterolateral) chest wall. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the aspect, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional detail using theoretical lines drawn through anatomical structures used to provide a consistent reference point on the human body.

Line running vertically which divides the body into left and right portions, passing through the head, spinal cord, and umbilicus. Alternatively it can refer to a line dividing a body part into two equal portions, for example a digit.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the apex of the axilla.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the anterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the posterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the midpoint of the clavicle.
Line running vertically down the face through the midpoint of the pupil when looking directly forward.
Line running vertically down the posterior surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the inferior point of the scapula.

annotations.comment: Common anatomical lines have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. The additional use of this data element allows for recording of the typical position of the heart's apex beat at 5th intercostal space, left side, and mid-clavicular line. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include anatomical line, then this data element is redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support the 'Body site name'.

annotations.comment: For example: adjacent to the vermilion border; a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.

localizedDescriptions.en: A physical site on or within the human body that is described in terms of the direction, and optionally the distance, of the site from a central landmark.
Identification of a single direction which represents the 12 o'clock or 0° position on an imaginary circle superimposed over the body site, as seen by the examiner.

annotations.comment: For example: the reference axis is commonly towards the head if examining the breast or detail on a skin lesion; towards the perineum if examining the anus in the lithotomy position; or towards the anterior humeral line if examining the humerus.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identified body site used as a reference point for centre of the imaginary circle.

annotations.comment: For example: the nipple when examining a breast; or the anus when examining haemorrhoids.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.
Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.
The body site is located at the one o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the two o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the three o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the four o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the five o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the six o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the seven o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the eight o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the nine o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the ten o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the eleven o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the twelve o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.

annotations.comment: For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock. In this situation the perineum is situated at 12 o'clock with patient in the lithotomy position, and regarded as the reference direction. For degrees, positive values are angles in the clockwise direction, while negative values are in the anti-clockwise direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.

annotations.comment: For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock. In this situation the perineum is situated at 12 o'clock with patient in the lithotomy position, and regarded as the reference direction. For degrees, positive values are angles in the clockwise direction, while negative values are in the anti-clockwise direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.

annotations.comment: For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock. In this situation the perineum is situated at 12 o'clock with patient in the lithotomy position, and regarded as the reference direction. For degrees, positive values are angles in the clockwise direction, while negative values are in the anti-clockwise direction.

For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock. In this situation the perineum is situated at 12 o'clock with patient in the lithotomy position, and regarded as the reference direction. For degrees, positive values are angles in the clockwise direction, while negative values are in the anti-clockwise direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Distance of location from the identified central landmark.
Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support structured data about the circular location.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Formula used to calculate the Mean Arterial Pressure (if recorded in data).
Formula used to calculate the systolic pressure from from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Formula used to calculate the diastolic pressure from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Presence of a pulse or heart beat.
A pulse or heart beat can be detected.
A pulse or heart beat cannot be detected.

annotations.comment: It can be implied that the pulse or heart beat is present if Rate >0 /min.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate of the pulse or heart beat, measured in beats per minute.
Regularity of the pulse or heart beat.
The pattern is regular.
The pattern is irregular.
More specific pattern of an irregular pulse or heart beat.
The pattern is irregular in a regular pattern,. For example, a dropped beat once every 'n' beats.
The pattern is irregular in a chaotic and unpredictable manner. For example, atrial fibrillation.

annotations.comment: Selection of a value from this value set is only valid if 'Irregular' is selected from the 'Regularity' data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the character of the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desired, where possible. For example: full, thready, bounding, slow rising, or collapsing. Multiple terms may be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the pulse or heart beat findings, including the rhythm.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the pulse or heart beat findings, including the rhythm.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the pulse or heart beat findings not captured in other fields.
The body position of the subject during the observation.
The subject was standing, walking or running.
The subject was sitting (for example on bed or chair).
The subject was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
The subject was lying flat.
Narrative description about any incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the physical findings.

annotations.comment: For example, presence of a pacemaker, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.

localizedDescriptions.en: Maximum pulse rate or heart rate observed during a period of exertion.
Presence of a pulse or heart beat.
A pulse or heart beat can be detected.
A pulse or heart beat cannot be detected.

annotations.comment: It can be implied that the pulse or heart beat is present if Rate >0 /min.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate of the pulse or heart beat, measured in beats per minute.
Regularity of the pulse or heart beat.
The pattern is regular.
The pattern is irregular.
More specific pattern of an irregular pulse or heart beat.
The pattern is irregular in a regular pattern,. For example, a dropped beat once every 'n' beats.
The pattern is irregular in a chaotic and unpredictable manner. For example, atrial fibrillation.

annotations.comment: Selection of a value from this value set is only valid if 'Irregular' is selected from the 'Regularity' data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the character of the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desired, where possible. For example: full, thready, bounding, slow rising, or collapsing. Multiple terms may be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the pulse or heart beat findings, including the rhythm.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the pulse or heart beat findings, including the rhythm.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the pulse or heart beat findings not captured in other fields.
The body position of the subject during the observation.
The subject was standing, walking or running.
The subject was sitting (for example on bed or chair).
The subject was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
The subject was lying flat.
Narrative description about any incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the physical findings.

annotations.comment: For example, presence of a pacemaker, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.

localizedDescriptions.en: Method used to observe the pulse or heart beat.
The findings are observed by physical touch of the observer on the subject.
The findings are observed with the assistance of a device, such as a stethoscope.
The findings are observed non-invasively using a device such as a pulse oximeter or a stethoscope.
The findings are observed invasively using a device such as an arterial catheter.

annotations.comment: For example, auscultation or electronic monitoring.

localizedDescriptions.en: Body site where the pulse or heart beat were observed.
The left radial artery.
The right radial artery.
The region of the heart.
The left carotid artery.
The right carotid artery.
The left femoral artery.
The right femoral artery.
The right brachial artery.
The left brachial artery.
An unspecified finger.
An unspecified toe.
The lobe of an unspecified ear.
